social_posts.post_text:
Santa needs a stocking, too!

Free pattern on leftinknots.com

Hey friends. It’s been a long time again. 

Life has gotten chaotic again. If you have been here a while, you may know this already but if you are new…

My husband has brain cancer.

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer. 

I am going to be hosting a fundraising pattern sale in hopes of raising money to fund his travel and related medical expenses for whatever comes next for our family. I am also going to be publishing a few new patterns this month that can be adapted to show support for any cancer you choose. 

I am going to use this opportunity to highlight related organizations funding cancer research and supporting brain cancer patients. 

If you would like me to promote a specific brain tumor foundation near and dear to your heart, or if you are going through a similar situation and would like me to help share your story please reach out to me in my DMs. 

If you feel triggered by cancer or medical stories, please feel free to mute me for the month. I understand. I will be returning to regularly scheduled crochet content after May. 

If you want a glimpse into the life of a brain cancer family, this is our story…

Our #braintumor story is a long one, and I’ll be sharing it @humansofny style (1/25). To purchase a crochet pattern fundraiser bundle visit the link in my profile. 

Almost exactly four years ago, I was plunged into the world of brain tumors.

I don’t even remember the first time I learned my husband had a brain tumor. We were acquaintances through a mutual friend before we started dating. I probably heard it second hand. 

When I met Eric, he was still sporting his “Fun Dip” hat. The one he had been wearing since his second brain surgery in his early 20’s.  The one we still have stashed away in our closet somewhere. Two brain surgeries by the time you’re in your 20’s. Can you imagine?  I’m married to him and I still can’t. 

Eric’s first surgery occurred as a teenager after the tumor was initially discovered. He was a young, healthy, varsity tennis player who just so happened to have a fairly large, lobed tumor growing in the area of his brain that affects speech. He was at a debate meet when his first seizure with speech loss occurred. A little bit of a cruel irony, but at least it made him and his family aware of the tumor. 

His first surgery had complications. I hear that there was bleeding. I was personally about 300 miles away, oblivious that my future husband was starting a journey that would shape the rest of his life and ours. The surgeon did the best that he could given the bleeding situation. The biopsy came back. Grade 2 brain tumor. I imagine that Eric and his parents felt some relief with that information. Grade 2 meant the tumor was benign. Maybe he was one of the lucky ones who would be able to walk away from the brain tumor world and never look back. But it turns out he wasn’t.

(2/25) 

To purchase a crochet pattern fundraiser bundle visit the link in my profile 🧠
 
I don’t actually know how they discovered that the tumor came back 5 years later. Routine MRI’s I suppose. This time, surgery went well. Again, I’ve only been told stories about this one because we hadn’t met yet. But I’m told that he sang Happy Birthday to one of the nurses while in surgery. 

Yep…this surgery was done while he was partially conscious. It’s necessary for tumors like his because the surgeon wants to make sure that they aren’t removing tissue that affects speech.  Thankfully, his speech was not affected, and again the tumor biopsy came back as a grade 2. 

The next year, we met and started dating. I heard some of the details of his tumor and surgeries, but it always seemed like something in the past. Something that was over and done. The second surgery was successful.  They got the whole tumor.

—-
May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month. I am sharing our family’s story this month and later today I hope to share my pattern sale fundraiser. Money will help pay for his medical expenses, travel, and things to make life easier so we can travel/do everything possible to continue treating his cancer. Thank you for taking the time to read our story ❤️🧠

#braintumorawareness #braincancerawareness #gograyinmay #crochetblogger #crochetersofinstagram

(3/25) My pattern sale fundraiser is live. You can find the link in my profile and stories 🧠**

We kept dating, fell in love, got married in a rain storm on Friday the 13th. We bought our first house, got our first “real” jobs, adopted cats and dogs, had 2 beautiful babies and all the other “life” stuff that is common to do in your 20s and early 30s. Neither of us had any idea. And maybe it was better that way. We got 10 years together of peaceful ignorance. We got the time to start and establish our life together. We got our two perfect children. I am so grateful for those years of ignorance.

It wasn’t until after our son was born that brain tumor recurrence number 3 happened. It was a crazy spring and summer. I had a c-section which led to many weeks of healing complications, we sold our home and bought a new one while I was postpartum (a particularly difficult time for me), and my son was the baby who NEVER slept. We were exhausted and sleep deprived. But we did it!  In September we moved into our new home and it felt so good to be done with that process. I remember telling my mom that I was so excited for life to feel routine again.  For life to slow down a little bit. What I didn’t know is that really was the start of this whole crazy season of life. And things have never truly settled down ever since.
———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month. I am sharing our family’s story this month and am having a pattern sale fundraiser. Money will help pay for his medical expenses, travel, and things to make life easier so we can travel/do everything possible to continue treating his cancer. Thank you for taking the time to read our story ❤️🧠

#braintumorawareness #braincancerawareness #gograyinmay #crochetblogger #crochetersofinstagram #graymay

My intention in sharing…

#braincancer #braincancersupport #braincancerawareness #fuckcancer #crochetblogger #crochetersofinstagram #gograyinmay #braintumorawareness

(4/25)

One night in November, we were piled in my daughters bed reading her bedtime stories.  My husband was reading to her when he got to a page where he stumbled over some words.  And then he didn’t say anything.  It was just a little pause; imperceptible to our 3 year old daughter at the time.  But Eric and I made eye contact and we knew, or at least suspected, he was having a small seizure like the ones he had prior to his brain tumor when he was younger.

I took the book and finished reading it to my daughter. Eric got over his seizure in just a few seconds.  We tucked my daughter in and said good night.  The next day he called his doctor

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer. 

I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in my profile. 

#crochetblogger #crochetpatterns #braincancer #braincancersupport #braintumorawareness

(5/25)

His primary care doctor got him in for an exam.  She told him that it was possible that stress and sleep deprivation could just catching up with him, but she wanted to schedule an MRI just to be thorough. The MRI results came back inconclusive.  Something minor was showing up, but it could just be scar tissue.  They would have to rescan in 6 months.

Those 6 months were our first taste of intense uncertainty.  Our first experience of living each day “trying not to think about it”. But every headache, every time his fingers tingled, every small stumble over a word raised our hackles and made us nervous.

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years. I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in my profile and stories

#braintumorawareness #gograyinmay #grayinmay #braincancerawareness #crochetpatterns #crochetcommunity #crochetblogger #crochet

(6/25)

Almost exactly 4 years ago, Eric’s next scan was coming up and each day got a little bit more nerve wracking. At one year old, our son was still not sleeping well and my mom came to stay with the kids so that we could go out to see a movie.  Unfortunately in that movie (I’m being intentionally vague to avoid giving spoilers) the dad had a young daughter, and he died at the end.  We left our movie date triggered and upset.

The next day was Mother’s Day; a day that we got through with forced smiles and what felt like obligatory celebration.  Because the next day was the day we were getting his scan results, and we both suspected what was coming.

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer. 

I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in my profile

#braintumorawareness #braintumor #crochet #crochetfundraiser #fundraiser #graymay #gogreyinmay #gograyinmay

(7/25)

“You can see the tumor has grown.  You will need surgery to remove it again.” the neurologist said as he closed the scan image. 

“How much did it grow?” I asked. 

“You saw the images.  It grew a noticeable amount.” he said. 

Great, we were getting the news that my husband’s tumor was back from a doctor who didn’t even take the time to answer our questions.  Thankfully, he suggested referring Eric back to the clinic where he had his second brain surgery (note: I am going to keep his treatment facilities and doctors anonymous for our privacy). That was fine with us, because neither of us liked this doctor much.  Although maybe you can never really like the doctor who tells you that your husband’s brain tumor is back for a third time….I don’t know

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t exactly know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer. 

I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in my profile. 

#crochet #crochetpattern #crochetaddict #braintumorawareness #braincancerawareness #braincancer #gograyinmay

(8/25)

We left the clinic that day, numb. We got home, numb. We went and distracted ourselves to process. We drove 6 hours to my husbands next appointment. The neuro oncologist confirmed that surgery was the next correct route to take. We met with the neurosurgeon, who reassured us that the surgery would likely go well. And he also had to inform us of the obvious risks. Brain damage, bleeding, death. We drove 6 hours home to be back with our kids, and to pretend for one more stretch of time like this wasn’t our reality.

The next few weeks were weird. There is really no other way to explain it. And it’s a weird that we have become extremely familiar with . Living in the motion of everyday life as a family with young children on one hand, and on the other hand walking around with the knowledge that life was going to become difficult and complicated to an unknown degree.  Learning to live in that mental dissonance has been, personally, one of my greatest challenges.

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t exactly know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer. 

I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in my profile. 

#crochetlove #crochetersofinstagram #graymay #cancersucks #fuckcancer #braincancerawareness #braintumorawareness

(9/25)

I’ll never forget the morning of my husband’s surgery.  We woke up very early in the hotel room we were staying in, and we didn’t talk much.  I packed myself some food and a crochet project to keep myself busy.  The check in process was long and tense.  Fear and dread were the prevailing emotions. We saw a rotating cast of nurses and aids who brought us paperwork, instructions and reassurance.  I sat as calmly as I could trying my best not to cry.  I nearly succeeded in holding myself together.

It wasn’t until they rolled Eric away that I allowed myself to fall apart. (I didn’t wait long enough though.  Later he would tell me that he heard me sobbing as they rolled him down the hall to surgery, but that he thought it was his mom.) The medical facility was large, and I couldn’t remember the directions I had been given to get to the waiting room.  I choked out a question to a nearby nurse, and she was kind enough to walk us there.  And so we sat and waited one of the longest waits I had experienced. I remember my thoughts vacillating from “please let him survive this, please let the surgery be successful” to “if he ever does need another surgery, please let it be in another 10 years”. I didn’t even consider any other possibilities.

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t exactly know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer. 

I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in my profile. 

#crochetpattern #crochetbundle #crochet #braintumorawareness #cancersucks #fuckcancer #gograyinmay

(10/25)

The three days spent in the hospital after my husbands surgery sounded like this:

“The surgery was a success”

“He had some seizures after the procedure”

“You did it, love!  You’ve got this.  You don’t have to talk”

“Your speech is already improving”

“I know I’m not supposed to, but can I stay with him?”

“My husband needs help! Something is wrong!”

“You will have to stay another day, you had another seizure”

“We got the pathology back.  Your tumor has become more aggressive.”

“I’ve got cancer…”

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t exactly know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer. 

I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in the comments.

#braintumortough #braincancersupport #braintumorawareness #braintumorsurvivor #crochet #crochetersofinstagram #crochetpattern #cancersucks #fuckcancer #gograyinmay #graymay

(11/25)

Officially, Eric’s tumor was now classified as a grade 3. Malignant. So we traveled back home much the way we had left.  Anxious, waiting for more information, and scared.  A few days later we got the news that Eric’s tumor had a specific genetic mutation.  This was good news because it meant he could be treated with a particularly helpful chemotherapy. But first they wanted to do specialized radiation.  The meeting to plan radiation was scary.  Phrases like “early dementia” “mood change” and “chronic fatigue” were presented as potential long term side effects.  We also learned that he would have to receive treatment every weekday for 6 weeks, 6 hours away from home.  It felt daunting and complicated to execute.

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t exactly know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer. 

I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in my profile. 

#braintumorstory #braintumorawareness #braintumor #braincancersupport #braincancer #crochetpattern #crochetblogger #crochetdesigner #cancersucks

(12/25)

I have always been thankful for the extreme flexibility my self-employment offers me, but never more than during Eric’s treatment. With the help of our family we were able to temporarily relocate. Just 9 months after moving into our new home we were packing again.  Our pets stayed with our parents while Eric, the kids and I moved into a small AirBnB.  The kids each got a bedroom, and Eric and I slept on the sectional in the living room.  Early every morning I got up before the sun with my son - who still didn’t sleep through the night - and every day, Eric went in to receive his radiation.

Aside from the sleeping situation and the reason we were there, we were able to find a lot of fun activities to do with the kids during the day.  I worked during nap time and in the evenings, and Eric was out on Short Term Disability.  It wasn’t ideal, but it was nice to be together as a family.

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t exactly know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer. 

I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in my profile

#gograyinmay #graymay #goforgray #braintumorawareness #braincancersucks #protonradiation #crochet #crochetsale #crochetpattern

(13/25)

The doctors were very pleased with Eric’s response to radiation.  He lost his hair, and experienced fatigue, but other than that he tolerated it well.  A good sign, they said.  He had a follow up scan in September that was clear, and we breathed a sigh of relief.  However in November, one year after his bedtime seizure, we received bad news.  The tumor was already growing again.  It was time to start chemo therapy.

It’s difficult to over state the amount of nervous anticipation you feel when you are waiting for insurance to approve a cancer treatment or procedure.  The thoughts go a lot like this: “will this work?” “will insurance cover this?” “how long will it take to get approval?” “gosh I hope the tumor isn’t growing too fast…” “things need to be happening faster!”

I want to take this moment to say that we have been WILDLY lucky when it comes to insurance.  It hasn’t been without its hiccups and headaches, but everything has so far been approved.  I know some aren’t as lucky. Eric’s chemo started, and again we breathed a sigh of relief that the tumor was being treated.  Unfortunately the drugs that weren’t supposed to cause very bad side effects had a rotten effect on my husband.

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t exactly know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer. 

I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in my profile. 

#crochetblogger #crochetersofinstagram #instacrochet #cancersucks #braincancerawareness #braintumortough #braintumorawareness

(14/25)

Eric experienced so many unpleasant side effects that his oncologist kept reducing the dose.  That made us both nervous because we also wanted this medication to work.  Thankfully, his first MRI after starting chemo showed the tumor was already responding and shrinking.

Then the Spring of 2020 happened.  The world came screeching to a halt, and we were on edge because we weren’t sure if my husband’s medical condition put him at greater risk.  But there was some comfort and peace for us in this time, too.  Again, we were together as a family.  Eric was working from home, my daughters preschool year got cut short, and expectations and responsibilities were at an all time low.  My son was (finally) sleeping through the night, and Eric’s tumor was improving, though not without unpleasant side effects.

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t exactly know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer. 

I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in my profile. 

#braincancer #chemotherapy #braintumor #braintumorawareness #crochetblogger #crochetlove #cancersucks

(15/25)

Six months after starting chemo, Eric’s oncologist suggested a break.  He wanted to give him time to recover from some side effects and also to see if the tumor would remain reduced in size.  Those two months were so nice, so pleasant, so normal feeling.  It was a hard crash back down to reality when we found out that he would have to restart chemo.

This time he would stay on the drugs longer.  A whole year.  It was a daunting future to walk into, but he never once complained.  I haven’t mentioned this yet, but my husband is brave, and joyful, and wonderful, and he doesn’t deserve this.  But I digress…

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t exactly know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer. 

I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in my profile. 

#braincancersucks #braincancersupport #braintumorawareness #cancersucks #crochetfundraiser #crochetforcancer #crochet #crochetersofinstagram

(16/26)

As we entered the second pandemic winter, we were homeschooling our daughter, keeping pretty isolated, and waiting for our turn for vaccines.  Eric was feeling all the same side effects that he felt during his first experience with chemo, and the side effects seemed to be compounding over time.  Six months into the year long treatment, I broke my ankle and couldn’t walk for nearly 3 months.  With both of us down and out, we called in reinforcement from our families.  We are so fortunate to have some family nearby and some family who will travel to be with us at the drop of a hat.

In mid summer, Eric’s oncologist decided he was happy with the progress his tumor had made on the chemotherapy.  He could no longer determine whether the MRI’s were showing tumor or scar tissue - a good sign that meant the tumor was reduced to a few cells or hopefully gone.  He got to take another two months off of chemo, and again it was two months of normal, happy family life that felt good, but now also strange and unfamiliar.

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t exactly know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer.

#chemotherapy #chemosucks #braintumorawareness #braincancerawareness #braintumor #cancersucks

(17/25)

I now feel like I’m repeating myself over and over (because this has repeated over and over). We waited two months, the tumor came back and this time it was a real blow. He was going to start chemo again.  This time his side effects came back quickly, along with some new ones that sent him to the hospital.  They lowered the dose again.  For a few months things were ok, but then Eric ended up in the hospital for a second time in the early spring of 2022.  They advised him to stop his chemo, and come for an MRI.

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t exactly know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis. #crochet #fundraiser #braincancer #grayinmay #gograyinmay #dadwithcancer #cancerstory #braintumorawareness #braincancerawareness

(18/25)

“This treatment doesn’t seem to be working anymore”

Long pause.  Spinning thoughts. What was next?  We left that appointment with a few hypotheticals, but nothing concrete.  A few weeks later we would learn of a clinical trial.  It was out of state, cross-country, but should be highly effective.  So we booked two plane tickets, again relying on family to stay with our kids and pets, and went to learn about this new potential chemo trial.

We flew down for just a few days, and came back with a lot of information.  Again, it felt daunting and complicated like it had before radiation.  And the parallels were there, too.  We would need to arrange a stay for 6 weeks over the summer.  There would be many appointments, blood tests and monitoring.  But first we had to wait for insurance.

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t exactly know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis. I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in my profile and stories

#braincancertreatment #braincancer #braincancersupport #braintumorawareness #cancerdad #crochetblogger #cancersucks #crochetersofinstagram

(19/25)

**Trigger Warning: medical emergency**

This time, the waiting period became detrimental. Two months without any treatment for my husband’s brain tumor turned out to be too long.  One morning during this waiting period, we woke up and got out of bed like usual.  Eric went downstairs before me, and I got our son up and ready.  When I got to the top of the stairs I knew immediately that something was wrong.

Eric was having a major seizure.  The kind where I had to call 911 and he was rushed to the hospital.  He lost conciousness.  He turned blue. I had to stay behind with the kids until my mother-in-law got to our house to watch them.  Eric was stabilized and in the hospital for one night. Thankfully we got to go home the next day.

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t exactly know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer. 

I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in my profile. 

#cancersucks #braincancerawareness #braintumor #braintumorsurvivor #braincancersupport #crochetblogger #crochet #crochetaddict #crochetlove

(20/25)

We heard from the Clinical Trial study coordinator the day he left our local hospital, and it was with frustrating news.  Eric had to be seizure free for two weeks before starting the trial.  His start date was delayed, and so we rebooked our flights and hotel reservation. 

We made the best of our time together at home with the kids.  This time they were staying home, and my plan was to travel for the beginning of the drug trial with Eric and come home after about a week and a half.  When the time came, we flew back down and worked on getting ourselves moved into a long term hotel.

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t exactly know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer. 

I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in my profile and stories. 

#clinicaltrials #braincancer #braincancerawareness #crochetblogger #crochetersofinstagram #braintumorawareness #grayinmay #graymay

(21/25)

A few appointments were separating Eric from his new treatment.  We were getting so close.  He had his scans, tests, meetings, signed his paperwork, and got his instructions.  He was scheduled to begin the trial the next day, but that didn’t happen. 

As we were leaving that last appointment, Eric told me he felt like he was having another seizure.  I ran down the hall to find a nurse, and they immediately sent him to the emergency department.  He was indeed having another (albeit smaller) seizure.

The occurrence of this seizure delayed plans further.  Thanks to the dedicated medical team, they were able to advocate for Eric to start the trial just one week later instead of two.  We changed my flight again so that I would stay longer, we extended his hotel reservation, and we waited on pins and needles in the hotel for the week hoping for no more seizures.

———

May is Brain Tumor Awareness Month - also known as Go Gray in May - and it is signified with a gray ribbon.  My husband has been battling a brain tumor that has steadily escalated in aggression for over 20 years.  Unfortunately its back again, and we don’t exactly know what his next steps will be or how it changes his prognosis.  For the indefinite future, he will be flying cross-country for treatment every 28 days.  Depending on what his next treatment options are, he may have to stay away from home longer. 

I am hosting a fundraising pattern sale to help fund his treatment and related travel expenses. Every pattern purchase helps, and we thank you so much for taking the time to read our family’s story. Link to the pattern sale is in my profile and stories. 

#braincancer #braincancerawareness #braintumor #clinicaltrials #medicalfamily #fuckcancer #crochetblogger #lovecrochet #crochetlove #crochetaddict #gograyinmay

22/25: my husband is currently battling brain cancer in the hospital and just had emergency brain surgery. I’m telling our story in May because it is Brain Tumor Awareness Month, and I am selling crochet pattern bundles to help fundraise for his medical expenses, time lost from work, etc. The link to purchase a bundle is in my profile. 

This is a continuation of our story:

Finally, on the day of our 10th wedding anniversary, we were up bright and early and headed to get him started on this chemo trial that we worked so hard to get him into.  He took the meds, and I simultaneously wanted to let out a huge sigh of relief while I was also tensed for action - waiting for any side effects.  This was a stage 1 clinal trial, so side effects and reactions weren’t well known and we didn’t know what to expect.

The side effects didn’t come.  Day 1 Eric tolerated this medication very well, then Day 2, Day 3 and Day 4.  After 5 days he was still feeling well.  At this point we decided it would be best for me to come home and be with the kids while Eric stayed, worked remotely from his hotel room, and finished the first 6 weeks of his chemo trial.

#braincancerawareness #braincancer #braintumor #braintumorawareness #fuckcancer #cancersucks #cancerfamily #cancercaregiver #crochet #crochetpatterns #crochetaddict #crochetlove

23/25: my husband is currently battling brain cancer and just had emergency brain surgery. I’m telling our story in May because it is Brain Tumor Awareness Month, and I am selling crochet pattern bundles to help fundraise for his medical expenses, time lost from work, etc. The link to purchase a bundle is in my profile. 

—this is a continuation of our story—

The moment of truth came at the end of his long stay.  He had another MRI just before he was scheduled to leave, and we got fabulous news!  The tumor was shrinking and quickly.  They were pleasantly surprised by how quickly it was responding to treatment. And aside from fatigue, Eric stayed free of unpleasant side effects.

Eric came home late in the summer, and thus began his travel cycle.  Twenty-five days at home, three days traveling for appointments, repeat like clockwork.  For the first few trips this process was smooth, but as we entered the holiday and winter months his flights got complicated and unpleasant.  He handled the delays and cancellations like a champ though.  As long as this chemo was working so well, these trips were absolutely worth it.

In March of this year, there was an unseasonably late blizzard that forced us reschedule his flight a few days early.  The morning of his appointment, I was at home, getting the kids ready for school, trying to keep myself focused instead of worrying.  I was doing a pretty good job too.  Until I realized that it was taking a very long time to hear from Eric about the results from his scan.

“The tumor seems to be growing again”. I wasn’t there, I don’t know if that’s what they said, but I’m sure it was something along those lines.  Eric texted me, and I shattered.  This was another sucker punch.  One that wasn’t even on our radar.  How could a drug that was working SO WELL just stop working after 7 months?!

Hey friends, thanks for being patient with me!  I’ve gotten so many messages recently checking in on our family. I can’t tell you how much it means to me ❤️ 

I didn’t mean to leave you with any kind of cliffhanger and I promise I will finish my husbands brain tumor story soon. But for now I can update that my husband is alive, relatively well, still dealing with a growing brain tumor and has a lot of recovery to do from his most recent medical emergency. We’ve been busy with a lot of rehabilitative appointments!

I hope you are all having a wonderful summer and I promise you will see some yarn on this account again soon(ish) 🧶

May was Brain Tumor Awareness Month and I had nearly finished sharing our family’s brain cancer story when my husband’s tumor threw us a major curveball. 

If you are just joining me now, feel free to go back several posts and read through the story. If you’re just here for the crochet - that’s what’s coming after this post 🧶❤️ If you want to follow along with more of my personal thoughts and experiences with cancer, I’ve started the account @midlife.caregiver 

*this is the remainder of our story up to this point*

They left us with a little bit of hope.  It could just be delayed tissue damage from radiation treatment.  They would need an MRI next month to compare the images.  Eric came back home and we spent the next month living in that strange space where life goes on, but your insides feel frozen.

Waiting for his appointment in April was agonizing. His headaches were getting more frequent. The next trip and MRI confirmed that the tumor was indeed growing despite the use of the trial drug. Our worst fears had been confirmed and his medical teams were back at the drawing board. Trying to figure out the next best steps. 

It was during this waiting period that Eric was rushed to the ER with what we though was another Grand Mal seizure. It turned out to be much worse. A large brain hemorrhage. 

I won’t take the time to explain all of the details of our hospital stay here. I will share more of that on @midlife.caregiver if you’re interested. 

The short story is that he didn’t receive the care he needed for over two days due to the negligence of one of his providers. On the third day a new doctor started at the hospital, examined Eric, and saved his life. He now has major struggles with aphasia and less dexterity on his right side, but he is alive and we are so grateful. 

Eric will be unable to work again for a long time - if ever. Our days are filled with rehabilitative appointments and parenting. Today is literally the first day I am trying to wrap my head around starting to work again. 

Crochet season is coming. This is my job and I want/need to work. I don’t know how to make it fit. 

Thank you for your support and patience during this crazy time.

🧶🧶🧶 I think I’m back?! 🧶🧶🧶

Ever since my husband was diagnosed with brain cancer 4 years ago, I have had a lot of trouble finding my “groove” when it comes to work. My kids need me, my husband needs me, life responsibilities need me, work needs me, and somewhere in there they tell me I’m also supposed to take some time for myself 🥴

On top of that, living with the knowledge that my husbands medical state can change quickly and at any time…I don’t know…I’ve been having a very hard time getting my footing. 

But today I have yarn in my hand, and I guess that’s a start. So tell me if you would. I’m thinking a blanket?  But I’d love to hear what you want to be making the next few months!  Help a girl out and give me an idea of a direction to take!

Thank you for sticking with me, even when I have to disappear for a while. 💜💙

Hey, friends. I have two updates for you today. One yarn-y and one personal. I’ll start with the yarn since I know that’s what most of you are here for!

I finally published a new pattern!  I love the stitch texture used in the Explorer’s Tote while it’s still a closed stitch, functional and durable bag. 

It feels good to get a pattern on the blog for the first time since early spring. You can find it at the link in my profile or at leftinknots.com. 

Why have I not published since then?  That brings me to the life update:

I am heartbroken to share with you that my husband’s brain cancer is progressing. We have now reached the point where we need to focus on making memories as a family over the next few months 💔

As much as I want and need to work, spending time with and taking care of my kids and husband is much more important at this point. I may publish a few patterns before the holidays, but only if I truly feel like I have the capacity to do so. 

I know many of you followed along with our story in May, and I endlessly appreciate your support, positive thoughts and prayers. 

I am also open to wisdom in regards to how to navigate anticipatory grief while still finding joy in the time our family is spending together. I’m not sure how to do this…

I hope you are all happy, healthy and ready to hibernate with your yarn soon 🧶💜 I will be back when I can be.

Hey! I’m Paula. Megan has been my best friend for-basically-ever. 👯‍♀️ (Why yes, this is a photo from prom 2003.)

Let me tell you, my life is so much better because she’s in it. 💜

As you know, Megan is an incredibly talented and creative crocheter. 🧶

But also (and more importantly) she’s a remarkable human being. ✨

🥰Megan cares deeply.
💜She loves fiercely.
😍And she can quote the entirety of Emperor’s New Groove without missing a beat.

Seriously, friends. Megan. Is. Awesome. 💯

She’s also been stretched thin over the past year.

If you were following along with her story in May, you know that Megan’s husband, Eric, is battling a brain tumor, and recently took a turn for the worse.

Since then, Megan, Eric, and their two kiddos, have been living in limbo, waiting.
…Waiting for doctors’ updates.
…Waiting for treatment options.
…Waiting to see if those treatments work.

Things are especially tough for her family right now, and as Megan focuses on creating memories, I thought I’d focus on sharing her crochet patterns with you. 💜

So for the next while, I’ll be:
🧶 recreating Megan’s incredible patterns
✅ offering tips I learn along the way
😍 sprinkling in some classic Megan stories that I think this community will love

I hope you’ll join me on the journey.

In fact, I’d love to know: what’s one of your favorite LeftInKnots patterns? Share it below, and I’ll add it to the list! 🧶

Then tap through the link in her bio to find your next fun project! 

—

Can we pause for a minute and talk about how fun this hat’s texture is?!

It’s called a lemon peel stitch 🍋

And the best part is you get that great texture with any type of yarn, whether it’s a simple acrylic or something like Lion Brand Scarfie.

Plus, the hat works up really quickly. 😍

A few nights on the couch with West Wing on in the background, and I had it done!

Want to make this hat for yourself?

Look at this texture! 😍 I've just started Megan's Spiked V-Stitch Cowl, and I can't get over the beautiful stitch.

Meg added a fun twist to the V-stitch to give the cowl a bit of extra texture while still staying light and airy. 

The V-stitch spikes down one extra row to overlap an HDC stitch row. The effect almost creates a faux-braided look, and it’s so pretty! 

Want to make your own? Get the free pattern on her website or an ad-free version on Etsy.

You can get to both through the link in her bio. Simply search for "Spiked v-stitch crochet cowl” on the site or “Crochet Blush Cowl Scarf“ on Etsy and it will pop right up!

I just finished my “between Christmas and New Year’s project,” and I am officially obsessed.😍

This is Megan’s oversized and textured ‘Autumn Chill Super Scarf,’ and it was so fun to make. 

The beautiful (yet easy to learn) stitches created such a delightful texture, and because it’s the same 3-4 stitches throughout, it’s a great contender for crochet-movie night. No counting required. 🎉

Megan’s original pattern calls for 2 full Caron Cakes of yarn; I wanted a bigger shawl to wrap around me when I’m on my coaching calls, so I went with 3 cakes instead. 

Want to make your own? Awesome! Snag the free pattern at leftinknots.com through the link in bio. 🔗 @leftinknots
